Scoring in every quarter and
flashing a pretty offense, the Hopkins team defeated Haverford College, 32-13 at Homewood Field last
Saturday night. It was the Jays'
first appearance at home in three
weeks and they obliged 4,000 shivering fans with quite an assortment
of football, some good, and some
not so good.
On the offense the Black and
Blue team looked well. In the
quartet of Lyons, Turnbull, Bauer,
and Hudert the locals appeared to
have plenty of power inasmuch as
there were several long marches in
which these men participated.
Loyns did exceptional work in his
first game on the home lot in two
years and his offside kicks between
the goal and the 10-yard line,
brought back memories to the
alumni and new hope to those who
had never seen him play before.
Jays Show Improvement
From a defensive point of view,
the Jays must show plenty of improvement before the games with
St. John's and Maryland. Saturday Haverford made twelve first
downs while the Black and Blue
eleven made two less. This fact becomes all the more impressive when
it is noted that the visitors were
unable to make one of these first
downs' on a forward pass. All the
Haverford gains were;through the
lines or around the ends,. It was
their failure in the aerial department that cost theni the game.
At the start of the game it appeared as though the jays would
have their hands full as Sirnons,
who gained consistently • for the
visitors all night, received Lyons'
kick-off on his 13-yard line and returned it to the Hopkins 45-yard
mark. He then carried the ball to
the Jays' 38-yard line and a 34-yard
pass to Conn had the. home team
battling in the shadow:of, their goal
posts..

Bauer intercepted a pass to place

stripe. From here, he and Turnbull carried it to the 34yard line
from which the latter -,.carried it
across for the first score of the, evening. Bauer added the:'e*a.. point

bars.
